Glitter and shine

The ability of a stone to refract light is called its “refractive index” and it determines the brilliance of the jewel. Moissanite has a higher refractive index, which makes it more brilliant than diamond. The glow of moissanite is multi-colored and all colors of light can be seen with the naked eye.

Hardness and durability

Diamond is the hardest material on planet Earth with a hardness of 10 on the Mohs scale. Moissanite is the second hardest and the average hardness of each stone is 9.5 on the Mohs scale.

Both stones have very high scratch resistance and brittleness. It is almost impossible to break or scratch a moissanite or diamond. While zirconia loses its shine over time, moissanite and diamond remain shiny even after years of use, making them timeless.

Ethics and environmental protection

There has long been a debate about diamond mining and how it affects the environment and the people involved in its extraction. The poor working conditions and conflicts that this industry creates cannot be underestimated.

Moissanite is created in controlled laboratory conditions and has a significantly smaller environmental footprint than diamond mining. The moissanite production process avoids the criticized diamond mining processes, which often result in the exploitation of human labor and a lasting harmful environmental footprint.

Moissanite holds the promise of a future where beauty and responsibility go hand in hand, and investing in timeless beauty has never been more worthwhile.
